Situation1: They occasionally tidy up visible clutter and do light cleaning in shared spaces.
Situation2: They notice a minor ethical dilemma at work, like someone cutting in line, and feel a mild urge to act.
Story: I push my cleaning cart down the hallway, the faint scent of disinfectant trailing behind me. My supervisor always reminds me: “Make sure every corner is spotless, even if it’s just a quick shift.” Today, I’m tidying the lounge, picking up stray wrappers and wiping tables, when I see a coworker slip ahead in the supply line, grabbing extra gloves before anyone else. It’s a small thing, but I know it’s unfair to the others waiting patiently. As a Hindu, I’m taught to uphold dharma—righteousness—even in small matters. My heart tugs at me to speak up, to gently remind my coworker about fairness. But I hesitate. If I say something, I might disrupt the easy flow of my work, maybe even draw unwanted attention or slow down my cleaning. My supervisor expects me to keep things running smoothly, not get involved in others’ business. I stand there, cloth in hand, torn between the urge to act according to my values and the pressure to keep my head down and focus on my job.
